review.title: An exact and two heuristic strategies for truthful bidding in combinatorial transport auctions
review.abstract: To support a freight carrier in a combinatorial transport auction, we proposes an exact and two heuristic strategies for bidding on subsets of requests. The exact bidding strategy is based on the concept of elementary request combinations. We show that it is sufficient and necessary for a carrier to bid on each elementary request combination in order to guarantee the same result as bidding on each element of the powerset of the set of tendered requests. Both heuristic bidding strategies identify promising request combinations. For this, pairwise synergies based on saving values as well as the capacitated p-median problem are used. The bidding strategies are evaluated by a computational study that simulates an auction. It is based on 174 benchmark instances and therefore easily extendable by other researchers. On average, the two heuristic strategies achieve 91 percent and 81 percent of the available sales potential while generating 36 and only 4 percent of the bundle bids of the exact strategy. Therefore, the proposed bidding strategies help a carrier to increase her chance to win and at the same time reduce the computational burden to participate in a combinatorial transport auction.

metadata.title: An exact and two heuristic strategies for truthful bidding in combinatorial transport auctions

sections.text: In order to assist a carrier in a combinatorial transport auction, we propose one exact heuristic strategy and two heuristic strategies for bidding on subsets of requests. The exact bidding strategy is based on the concept of elementary request combinations. We show that it is sufficient and necessary for a carrier to bid on each elementary request combination to guarantee the same result as bidding on each element of the power set of the advertised requests. Both heuristic bidding strategies identify promising request combinations, using pairs of synergies based on savings values and the capacity p-median problem. The bidding strategies are evaluated by a computer study simulating an auction. They are based on 174 benchmark instances and can therefore be easily expanded by other researchers. On average, the two heuristic strategies achieve 91 percent and 81 percent of the available sales potential, with only 36 percent and 4 percent of the bundle bids of the exact strategy being generated.

sections.heading: 2. A bundle bid generation problem
sections.text: The problem of Bundle Bidding (BGP) must be solved by each carrier participating in a Combinatorial Transport Auction. A carrier c must decide what subsets of transport requirements he offers and what price he charges. Carrier c aims to maximize his revenue from the auction, i.e. the sum of the prices of his bundled bids accepted by the auctioneer. What complicates BGP is the distribution of the problem. On the one hand, there are competing carriers making competing bundle bids, the composition and prices of which carrier c is unaware of, i.e. there is asymmetric information. On the other hand, the decision-making power to accept which bids as winners lies not with carrier c, but with the auctioneer, i.e. there are several decision-makers with distributed decision-making power.

sections.heading: 2.2. Assumptions on the tendered transport requests and the bidding carrier
sections.text: We consider a freight forwarder whose customers must be served by LTL requests from the shipper's warehouse. In terms of the structure of the transport requirements and the transport company, our transport scenario is based on the known capacity vehicle routing problem (CVRP) with the following modifications and additional assumptions. • The freight forwarder operates a single warehouse from which a specific V of the customers must be served. • The freight forwarder in question operates a fleet of homogeneous vehicles. The capacity of each vehicle is limited. • The freight forwarder offers a specific R of the requests. Each request r requires a collection of the cargo from the shipper's warehouse and its delivery to a customer location i. We assume that there is exactly one request for each customer, i.e. that the shipper writes out a specific R of the requests.

sections.text: Although intelligent systems to support transport decisions are proliferating, the optimal bidding strategy remains a mathematical challenge as the number of tendered requests increases. Therefore, we propose two additional heuristic bidding strategies: they are called pair synergy-based request clustering (PSC) and capacified p-median request clustering (PMC), both of which attempt to identify a subset of elementary bids that are promising. sections.text: We evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed bidding strategies on the basis of a computational benchmark study. sections.text: The EBBS, PSC, CPMC strategies differ significantly in terms of computing time. For all 209 solved cases (including the 35 cases with f b = 0), the mean runtime for EBBS, PSC, CPMC is 152 seconds, 9 seconds, and 3 seconds, respectively. However, the average runtime for EBBS, PSC, CPMC is 153 minutes, 20 minutes, and 0.75 minutes, respectively. The average success rate for CPMC is an order of magnitude faster than PSC, and PSC is an order of magnitude faster than EBBS. Therefore, heuristic strategies are a serious alternative to EBBS when the trade-off between used sales volume and runtime is taken into account.

Generation of benchmark instances The bidding strategies are compared by means of benchmark instances. An instance consists of a set R of requests tendered by the auctioneer and a set Br of bundle bids of the rivals of carrier c. Furthermore, the vehicle capacity cap is given. All in all, 240 instances have been generated in which between 15 and 40 requests are tendered and up to 5000 bids of rivaling carriers are present. The set of requests is implicitly defined by a depot node d and a set V of customer nodes, each with a required load li (i ∈ V). The warehouse node w and the depot node d are set equal, as explained below. The distance between two nodes is calculated as the Euclidean distance (L2-norm) rounded to the nearest integer value. The customer nodes and demands are taken from the popular instances2 of the capacitated vehicle routing problem introduced by Christofides et al. (1979). The first node of a CVRP instance is used as the depot node d.

metadata.abstractText: To support a freight carrier in a combinatorial transport auction, we proposes an exact and two heuristic strategies for bidding on subsets of requests. The exact bidding strategy is based on the concept of elementary request combinations. We show that it is sufficient and necessary for a carrier to bid on each elementary request combination in order to guarantee the same result as bidding on each element of the powerset of the set of tendered requests. Both heuristic bidding strategies identify promising request combinations. For this, pairwise synergies based on saving values as well as the capacitated p-median problem are used. The bidding strategies are evaluated by a computational study that simulates an auction. It is based on 174 benchmark instances and therefore easily extendable by other researchers. On average, the two heuristic strategies achieve 91 percent and 81 percent of the available sales potential while generating 36 and only 4 percent of the bundle bids of the exact strategy. Therefore, the proposed bidding strategies help a carrier to increase her chance to win and at the same time reduce the computational burden to participate in a combinatorial transport auction.
